componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Andrew Buscaglia of Credit Suisse.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just looking at your volumes too. I mean, so now we've got our second quarter in a row of positive volumes. How did it track towards where you guys were expecting in the quarter? I know we had a lot of noise last quarter. But were these better than you
componenttext: So just looking at your volumes too. I mean, so now we've got our second quarter in a row of positive volumes. How did it track towards where you guys were expecting in the quarter? I know we had a lot of noise last quarter. But were these better than you expected and then how did things trend through July, so far?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd say they're a little bit ahead of where we expected. Like I said, the commercial line of business has been a very easy pattern to follow. The March has been very steady at about 0.5 to 1 point of improvement every quarter. Obviously, the industri
componenttext: Yes, I'd say they're a little bit ahead of where we expected. Like I said, the commercial line of business has been a very easy pattern to follow. The March has been very steady at about 0.5 to 1 point of improvement every quarter. Obviously, the industrial line is a little bit more seasonal and we probably had some of those volumes move into the first quarter with the stronger construction season in the first quarter. The landfill line, again, has been a pretty steady March. Again, a little bit of extra volume probably in the first quarter. So I'd say we're a little bit ahead where we are. But we don't expect the trend to change. That's why we think that we're on a very good march toward that positive 1% plus volume by the end of the year.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, the big question that we have really at the end of the first quarter was how much volume did we borrow because of the mile load that David mentioned, how much did we borrow in Q1 from Q2? And that borrowing would've occurred really in 2 lines of b
componenttext: Andrew, the big question that we have really at the end of the first quarter was how much volume did we borrow because of the mile load that David mentioned, how much did we borrow in Q1 from Q2? And that borrowing would've occurred really in 2 lines of business. It would have occurred in the roll off line of business, primarily within the temporary roll off component. And then it would have occurred in the landfill line of business. And then looking at it, it looks like if you adjust that kind of the added workday we had in Q1, we think we'd probably borrowed somewhere in the neighborhood of 60 to 80 basis points of volume in those 10 [ph] lines of business. But still, when you look at 150-basis-point improvements in industrial versus last year and commercial being up 200 basis points, which didn't see any borrowing from Q1 to Q2, we felt pretty good about volume in Q2. And as David said, probably a little bit ahead of where we expected to be particularly on the commercial line.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with respect to the last part of the question obviously, it's still early. But July volumes continued to show the steady progression.
componenttext: And with respect to the last part of the question obviously, it's still early. But July volumes continued to show the steady progression.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let's go ahead into July. I mean, you said you could probably do better than that 1%. But I guess, what's the hesitation there? I mean, are there some pretty large contracts rolling off in Q3 and Q4? Or is it just tough comps? Or what I guess, what
componenttext: Okay. Let's go ahead into July. I mean, you said you could probably do better than that 1%. But I guess, what's the hesitation there? I mean, are there some pretty large contracts rolling off in Q3 and Q4? Or is it just tough comps? Or what I guess, what do we expect into the second half?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Obviously, the comps get a little bit tougher than that. So no, there are no big contracts. In fact, we have a couple of contracts on the national accounts side that will be coming on at the back half of the year. So there really aren't any large vol
componenttext: Yes. Obviously, the comps get a little bit tougher than that. So no, there are no big contracts. In fact, we have a couple of contracts on the national accounts side that will be coming on at the back half of the year. So there really aren't any large volume losses like we've had in the past few years particularly in the residential line kind of business. But there are a little bit tougher year-over-year comps.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Hoffman of Stifel.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I had a question on the price side. You noted that you had a delta of about 80 basis points year-over-year on the core. But you had a 90 basis points on the yield in the inside solid waste. So clearly, that's the right direction, you're retaining more
componenttext: So I had a question on the price side. You noted that you had a delta of about 80 basis points year-over-year on the core. But you had a 90 basis points on the yield in the inside solid waste. So clearly, that's the right direction, you're retaining more price within the core. What are you doing proactively to offset the leakage from, it was 450-ish million of price you're going to the market with versus what you were reporting?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael as you heard us talk, that's our periscope project, and Jim Trevathan is leading that, so maybe he can talk a little bit about what we're doing with periscope.
componenttext: Yes, Michael as you heard us talk, that's our periscope project, and Jim Trevathan is leading that, so maybe he can talk a little bit about what we're doing with periscope.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael. You noticed well because that is absolutely true. Part of it can be mix that we don't have control over. But what we do have control over, we're seeing the benefit of that. We're retaining more of that price. Periscope, it's a self-service a
componenttext: Yes, Michael. You noticed well because that is absolutely true. Part of it can be mix that we don't have control over. But what we do have control over, we're seeing the benefit of that. We're retaining more of that price. Periscope, it's a self-service analytical platform. It really marries kind of revenue costs unit data. It gives us profitability and trending profitability. We can do it, Michael, by customer. By sales rep, we can do it by customer segment or a sales channel, by route, by geography. It really will help us as we move forward. We're about halfway through rolling it out to our 17 [ph] areas. Not all of them are executing with it. We're in the final steps of putting together a playbook that really will be -- because the analytics are so intuitive and so obvious, it'll be really heavy on action. What do we with the tool to get benefit. Most of that will come as we finish the rollout in Q4 and especially into 2017. But for those areas that have been headed up and running, we see the benefit. We also see some real strong and persistent execution by our teams on retaining those higher margin customers. And I think that plays into that yield positive as well. We've got really good processes that are being executed across the areas to retain customers and our operating team is providing a lot better service that we measure really consistently with real accountability process. So I think that trend will continue.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And based on the early rollouts where it's been in for a while. What's the pace of that gap narrowing? I mean, is a 10 basis points a quarter? Or is it 20 or 30 basis points a quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And based on the early rollouts where it's been in for a while. What's the pace of that gap narrowing? I mean, is a 10 basis points a quarter? Or is it 20 or 30 basis points a quarter?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Michael, we've got -- I don't have the number in front of me, but we piloted in the south East. And it's one of our highest yield and our most improved from a retention standpoint area. So we see the benefit of that from that area, using it and implementi
componenttext: Michael, we've got -- I don't have the number in front of me, but we piloted in the south East. And it's one of our highest yield and our most improved from a retention standpoint area. So we see the benefit of that from that area, using it and implementing the tool.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on volume. If I follow the path of the sequential progression and you exit the year at over 1%, but it feels like you start the year at almost 2%, based on that -- I mean, the reported number will be over 1. But you're starting '17 at 2 on
componenttext: Okay. And then on volume. If I follow the path of the sequential progression and you exit the year at over 1%, but it feels like you start the year at almost 2%, based on that -- I mean, the reported number will be over 1. But you're starting '17 at 2 on volume. Am I being overly optimistic about your volume outlook for 2017?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Obviously, we put our budgets together in the October, November time frame. So we'll look at it then and where we are at that point in time. But what I've said Michael is I do think we're progressing toward that, what I call the 2% price, 2% volume,
componenttext: Yes. Obviously, we put our budgets together in the October, November time frame. So we'll look at it then and where we are at that point in time. But what I've said Michael is I do think we're progressing toward that, what I call the 2% price, 2% volume, that's 2 and 2. I've said that is probably 18 months away. But as we put together our budgets for 2017, hopefully we'll see it on the horizon a little sooner.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then there's a lot of handwringing in the stock market about the economy, and recession here and there, Brexit and all that. Can we break in to 2 sort of pieces of your business, the runs that approximately $1 billion that's in industrial. If I
componenttext: Okay. And then there's a lot of handwringing in the stock market about the economy, and recession here and there, Brexit and all that. Can we break in to 2 sort of pieces of your business, the runs that approximately $1 billion that's in industrial. If I pull out the energy waste business, which I guess is down for secular reasons, what's the rest of the trend? And are you seeing any recessionary signs?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's interesting because you hear everybody talking about this industrial recession that's going on in the U.S. And I would say, we're not seeing it. Our C&D volume, which is part of the industrial line of business and then our special waste volumes a
componenttext: No. It's interesting because you hear everybody talking about this industrial recession that's going on in the U.S. And I would say, we're not seeing it. Our C&D volume, which is part of the industrial line of business and then our special waste volumes are probably the best gauges of the economy -- that part of the economy and they're pretty strong, both were solid in Q2. June was the strongest month of the quarter. And July showed continued strength. So we're just not seeing the industrial recession. Now maybe it's because we're at the back end of the cycle. But I would tell you, we're -- even when we look at our special waste pipeline, it looks pretty strong. So I would tell you, we're not seeing with the rest of the country seems to be talking about.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Michael, I'm not sure when the country talks about industrial recession, I think they're thinking about things like automobiles and refrigerators. I think Houston is sort of indicative of the country, which is the Westside of Houston is not doing so g
componenttext: And Michael, I'm not sure when the country talks about industrial recession, I think they're thinking about things like automobiles and refrigerators. I think Houston is sort of indicative of the country, which is the Westside of Houston is not doing so great because of low oil prices. But the Eastside of Houston when you go to Beaumont, Lake Charles, the spots where we have our industrial landfill base, because of the low energy price input, those places are booming. You can't buy a house in Beaumont, not that anyone would want to. That's a wonderful city. But the chemical corridor is doing spectacularly well, certainly as not in any kind of industrial recession, so when we look at our overall industrial business, it's actually performing very well.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I follow that through on the consumer side. So every restaurant company in the country, that's casual or fast casual is reporting lousy comps. So yes, you have shown positive commercial volume. And I think the restaurant comp issue is th
componenttext: Okay. And then if I follow that through on the consumer side. So every restaurant company in the country, that's casual or fast casual is reporting lousy comps. So yes, you have shown positive commercial volume. And I think the restaurant comp issue is they thought their comps were going to be 3 and 4, and they're coming in at 1 and 2, and that's deemed lousy. How do you see like the commercial market in the context of like end markets like restaurants or the entertainment or services sector?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the overall commercial business, as Jim Trevathan mentioned with about 60% to 70% of our new business coming from Greenfield, which is our brand new operating businesses, it seems to us that the whole commercial end market is very strong. We don't lo
componenttext: Yes, the overall commercial business, as Jim Trevathan mentioned with about 60% to 70% of our new business coming from Greenfield, which is our brand new operating businesses, it seems to us that the whole commercial end market is very strong. We don't look at it necessarily by the various segments. But the end market actually seems to be very strong.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Now last one for me. On your free cash flow raise 1 6 to 1 7. How many dollars of onetime that are unique to '16 are in that 1 6 to 1 7?
componenttext: All right. Now last one for me. On your free cash flow raise 1 6 to 1 7. How many dollars of onetime that are unique to '16 are in that 1 6 to 1 7?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's probably 3 numbers that really matter in that, Michael. You've got the onetime CapEx piece and that's about 100. And that's offset by kind of a onetime cash flow monetization -- cash taxes monetization. So those 2 offset one another at about
componenttext: Yes. There's probably 3 numbers that really matter in that, Michael. You've got the onetime CapEx piece and that's about 100. And that's offset by kind of a onetime cash flow monetization -- cash taxes monetization. So those 2 offset one another at about 100 a piece. And then you've got just the business itself growing in about $100 million coming in through the EBITDA line.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Corey Greendale with the First Analysis.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Corey Greendale with the First Analysis.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ken Lang [ph] on for Corey. Just focusing on the decline in recycling volume this quarter, which I believe may be part of the volume you're shedding. Can you speak about the dynamics here, just given that commodity prices have been on an upward tr
componenttext: This is Ken Lang [ph] on for Corey. Just focusing on the decline in recycling volume this quarter, which I believe may be part of the volume you're shedding. Can you speak about the dynamics here, just given that commodity prices have been on an upward trajectory recently?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The bulk of those volume declines were large contracts where we were losing money. And we rebid them to make money and someone else took the contract. And so those were -- losing those volumes were the best thing we can do for recycling because they
componenttext: Yes. The bulk of those volume declines were large contracts where we were losing money. And we rebid them to make money and someone else took the contract. And so those were -- losing those volumes were the best thing we can do for recycling because they were literally negative margin volumes.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then kind of on the same topic, I know you put in place recycling contracts that limit pricing exposure, and again with prices up for commodities, how will this affect the bottom line? Is there kind of a formula that you can give
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then kind of on the same topic, I know you put in place recycling contracts that limit pricing exposure, and again with prices up for commodities, how will this affect the bottom line? Is there kind of a formula that you can give us or some kind of rule of thumb?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you look, prices are up not dramatically just in that 2% to 3% range for the quarter. So not a dramatic increase in price. And as we look forward, remember, every year, you seemed to have that seasonal uptick. And then starting in July, it starts
componenttext: Yes. And you look, prices are up not dramatically just in that 2% to 3% range for the quarter. So not a dramatic increase in price. And as we look forward, remember, every year, you seemed to have that seasonal uptick. And then starting in July, it starts to tick down. So we're not certain that we're going to see that benefit in the back half the year. But generally what we say is that every $10 in commodity prices equates to about $30 million of EBIT for us. And so what we tried to do in this business is to make sure that if commodity prices go down, our earnings don't take a negative hit. But if commodity prices go up, they take a positive hit. So we tried to derisk the business so that there's no downside, only upside. If the commodity prices go down the back half of the year, we think we can offset that with operational improvement. So we don't expect any negative benefit in the back half the year if we see anything in the back half of the year, it will be a positive benefit for recycling.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you look at the whole first half of the year on recycling while we're up in commodity prices for Q2 by about 2.3%, we're actually down still year-to-date over 4% in commodity prices. And to David's point, we think that will probably even out. We're
componenttext: And if you look at the whole first half of the year on recycling while we're up in commodity prices for Q2 by about 2.3%, we're actually down still year-to-date over 4% in commodity prices. And to David's point, we think that will probably even out. We're cautiously optimistic because of the dynamic that he mentioned with kind of high prices in Q2 and then it telltale off in Q3 and Q4. But we're cautiously optimistic that we might be able to get to flat pricing. All the benefit that you're seeing from recycling, a big chunk of benefit you're seeing for recycling for us, has been on the OpEx side where we've taken quite a bit of OpEx out for the first 6 months and then we'll continue to do so in the back half.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Al Kaschalk of Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Al Kaschalk of Wedbush Securities.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the recycling piece, maybe you can talk a little bit further on that please, clarification. A couple of years ago, you called out, and I think it was actually dollar valued sort of the improvement that you were looking for operationally. A lot of it wa
componenttext: On the recycling piece, maybe you can talk a little bit further on that please, clarification. A couple of years ago, you called out, and I think it was actually dollar valued sort of the improvement that you were looking for operationally. A lot of it was through negotiating and renegotiating contracts, some of the commodity price headwinds et cetera. But where are we in terms of that tailwind on the improvement? You earned $0.01, I think this quarter or you commented, I think you got $0.01, which is the first time you turned profitable on a while. And so let's just leave it at that, and you take it from there to see if you could share an update on where you're at.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. We're about 75% to 80% of the way through what I call those negative margin contracts. We still have a couple more that will roll off over the next 6 to 9 months. And so, and that's why I say in the back half of the year, being 75% to 80% throu
componenttext: Yes, sure. We're about 75% to 80% of the way through what I call those negative margin contracts. We still have a couple more that will roll off over the next 6 to 9 months. And so, and that's why I say in the back half of the year, being 75% to 80% through those contracts obviously, we still have 20% to 25% that has some exposure to downward commodity prices. But if that 20% or 25% seems downward commodity prices, we do think that we can offset that with operational improvement. So that's why I say the back half the year, there really is only upside from recycling. There really isn't much downside. Now as we look back in the back half of the year, we're not counting on a dramatic commodity price increase. But any commodity price increase that we have obviously, false straight to the bottom line.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Are you hearing from customers in terms of new service ads in this area or are people, I guess probably I guess in particular are they still -- do they get it yet in terms of understanding the cost? I know your messaging has been very direct th
componenttext: All right. Are you hearing from customers in terms of new service ads in this area or are people, I guess probably I guess in particular are they still -- do they get it yet in terms of understanding the cost? I know your messaging has been very direct there. But what's the feedback that you're getting as folks are looking at the service?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Look, I think they get it. It's been a very prolonged downturn. This has been a different downturn than we've ever seen in the recycling market. So I think they get it. Now early on in the cycle, you had some people that came in and did some of these
componenttext: Yes. Look, I think they get it. It's been a very prolonged downturn. This has been a different downturn than we've ever seen in the recycling market. So I think they get it. Now early on in the cycle, you had some people that came in and did some of these contracts under the old methodology, right? And they're not very happy with those contracts right now. So in my mind, it sort of follows the same cycle that we saw with the fuel surcharge back in the early 2000's where initially, people go well, we'll count on the market bouncing back so will continue to bid under the old model. They're now stuck with 3- to 5-year contracts where they're going to lose money for 3 to 5 years. The next time those contracts come up, they will be bid more rationality. So not only do the municipalities get it, but I think the recycling community gets it too. I think what you'll see is a much more rational bidding behavior over the next 5 years.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Switching gears on the industrial side. You guys were on a record of talking about this being a very, very strong growth area for you. But suggesting to me, it was more M&A implied but also organically. Could you talk about the environment there? There ce
componenttext: Switching gears on the industrial side. You guys were on a record of talking about this being a very, very strong growth area for you. But suggesting to me, it was more M&A implied but also organically. Could you talk about the environment there? There certainly have been a few companies that have struggled in this area. We've had a fair amount of tailwind from sort of the energy concept which largely now I think has dissipated out of the numbers, so-called easy comps. But -- and then I think Jim made some comments earlier about C&D in special ways. But let's talk about, you put out 9.5% price, which I think was pretty -- did I get that number right? Correct. Where do we go from here?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Al, there's a couple of components of that industrial line of business. It's a big category. Of course, energy services, I mean we've had some questions when we've been out talking to investors about, you're seeing your energy services coming back because
componenttext: Al, there's a couple of components of that industrial line of business. It's a big category. Of course, energy services, I mean we've had some questions when we've been out talking to investors about, you're seeing your energy services coming back because you're seeing price go, bouncing back up. And what we said is look, energy services is really not so much driven by the price of oil as it is driven by drilling activity, and we've not seen drilling activity rebound in the form of rig count. So the energy services piece is still pretty soft, year-over-year. It's a pretty big negative for us that we fought back against. Coal ashes another components. Coal ash, as you know, we have a big Duke contract that is proceeding well for us. And we're seeing some -- certainly seeing some landfill impact from that contract. The utilities, the public utilities out there, developing their coal combustion residual plants for each plant. And we expect that those plants will result in a combination of kind of on-site work and some off-site disposal for us in the next few years. So coal ash will be good. I would tell you that for the most part, these companies preferred a handle on site, preferred beneficial reuse. We can handle all 3, but we'll certainly see in addition to the Duke contract. C&D, we talked about -- c&D has been strong and I would tell you, I've been talking to one of our area vice presidents who has a strong C&D market right now, he believe that, that's part of what's affecting his commercial volume. David has said it many times, it's -- when you start seeing this big tracts of land being taken out and we get that C&D business, maybe the more beneficial side of that is getting the commercial volume, the permanent business on the back end of that. And this VP seems to think that's exactly what's going on. And there are a couple of other components within the industrial line of business as well. But overall, I think industrial looks to be reasonably strong for us and it appears to be continuing down that path.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Jim, on your coal ash opportunity. There are a couple of companies, one in particular that has a fair amount of relationships with the utilities on sort of selling that ash out for beneficial reuse. Is M&A an opportunity for you guys here, understa
componenttext: Great. Jim, on your coal ash opportunity. There are a couple of companies, one in particular that has a fair amount of relationships with the utilities on sort of selling that ash out for beneficial reuse. Is M&A an opportunity for you guys here, understanding that disposal or the off-site work you certainly are set up for. But I'm wondering about the on-site work and the marketing of ash.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So M&A is an opportunity for us there. We bought a company called Flash Direct a couple of years ago. And they have really grown tremendously since the acquisition, since we acquired them a couple of years ago. So while we're always looking for propr
componenttext: Yes. So M&A is an opportunity for us there. We bought a company called Flash Direct a couple of years ago. And they have really grown tremendously since the acquisition, since we acquired them a couple of years ago. So while we're always looking for proprietary technologies, that's what Flash Direct brought to us, right now we feel good with that acquisition. But not to say we wouldn't look at another acquisition there or in any other space and energy services for example. You've got to be properly priced and we don't want to kind of buy it at the bottom. And we can talk about M&A later. But yes, we'd certainly be interested in acquisitions. We just need to make sure it's the right technology and provides the right returns.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Finally, David, if I can come back to your comment on your prepared remarks. I think you said that core price, 4%; yield was 2%. And then you followed that with it could moderate in the second half of '16. Help me appreciate what you were a -- I won't say
componenttext: Finally, David, if I can come back to your comment on your prepared remarks. I think you said that core price, 4%; yield was 2%. And then you followed that with it could moderate in the second half of '16. Help me appreciate what you were a -- I won't say.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, what I meant Al, was our original targets were 4%, core price; 2%, yield. We're going to exceed those. There's no doubt about. It. This quarter, it was 4.9. So well above our target and 2.6, well above our 2% target. So on the back half of the ye
componenttext: Yes. No, what I meant Al, was our original targets were 4%, core price; 2%, yield. We're going to exceed those. There's no doubt about. It. This quarter, it was 4.9. So well above our target and 2.6, well above our 2% target. So on the back half of the year, we've got some CPI headwinds. We've got some year-over-year comp issues. We got the timing of price increases. So it might moderate a little bit. But nothing dramatic, nothing that will dramatically affect profitability. We still expect to have a great back half of the year. And for the full year, we'll clearly exceed that 4% core price target and that 2% yield target.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you are saying moderating from the 4.9 and 2.6?
componenttext: Okay. So you are saying moderating from the 4.9 and 2.6?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Kaye of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Noah Kaye of Oppenheimer.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if we can touch on the residential portion of the business, you did shed some of the unprofitable volumes. Can you give us an update on how you're tracking with migrating to the waste CPI sub index? Something that I know certainly competito
componenttext: Just wondering if we can touch on the residential portion of the business, you did shed some of the unprofitable volumes. Can you give us an update on how you're tracking with migrating to the waste CPI sub index? Something that I know certainly competitors has talked about quite a bit. Can you give us a way to sort of measure where you are on the progress of that initiative?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jim Trevathan here, we absolutely are focused on, not just with the residential line of business, but with our natural account business. With CPI obviously, below 1 and not looking for any real strength in that number. We have migrated in that regard. We'
componenttext: Jim Trevathan here, we absolutely are focused on, not just with the residential line of business, but with our natural account business. With CPI obviously, below 1 and not looking for any real strength in that number. We have migrated in that regard. We're on new contracts, that is the goal on every new contract to have a metric that's closer to our cost increases rather than CPI. And we're in the side, probably 1/3 [ph] of the way through on the national accounts side. We're getting a different metric on every renewal of a contract. It may not be the floor wastewater treatment generally 200, 300 basis points higher than CPI. But we see that as the way forward to minimize the margin deterioration as our costs go up. But yet CPI stays below 1, so that is absolutely a focus and we're a little less than halfway through. But again, those our long-term contracts. So as they change, that's the goal.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, even with the positive progress that Jim just talked about on shifting between these contracts. It's so secret that resi is a top line of business for us. And I think it -- to me, it highlights the need for good solid disposal pricing. And we believe
componenttext: No, even with the positive progress that Jim just talked about on shifting between these contracts. It's so secret that resi is a top line of business for us. And I think it -- to me, it highlights the need for good solid disposal pricing. And we believe that we've made some progress on disposal pricing not as much as we would like, part of -- you'll see an improvement as the charge kind of -- how do we put it the last quarter, actually started on July 1, starts to kind of come to fruition. But look, that line of business has in all honesty, has been a disappointed for us. We're doing a lot to try to fix it. And part of that is addressing it on the disposal side of our business.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Noah, an example of that business of the residential line, we were over 2% in the yield for the quarter where we haven't been over 2% for a couple of years on the resi line of business. But we're making a real progress, it's measurable.
componenttext: And Noah, an example of that business of the residential line, we were over 2% in the yield for the quarter where we haven't been over 2% for a couple of years on the resi line of business. But we're making a real progress, it's measurable.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that is incredibly helpful. That additional $100 million to $200 million of free cash flow a nice upward provision there. I'm wondering kind of how you can think about allocation generally these days, how are you looking at the M&A landscape. Certai
componenttext: Okay, that is incredibly helpful. That additional $100 million to $200 million of free cash flow a nice upward provision there. I'm wondering kind of how you can think about allocation generally these days, how are you looking at the M&A landscape. Certainly rising tide, flipout boats and the potential evaluations, but we are seeing more industry discipline in a number of fronts. So I'm wondering how you're thinking about the M&A opportunities, and also what kind of opportunities you're seeing for any kind of asset swaps and market consolidation.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When we look at the acquisition market, basically the last 3 years we've done a moderate-sized deal each year, but added sort of that $50 million to $75 million of EBITDA. So we did Deffenbaugh RCI in Montreal, Deffenbaugh in Kansas City and SWF in S
componenttext: Yes. When we look at the acquisition market, basically the last 3 years we've done a moderate-sized deal each year, but added sort of that $50 million to $75 million of EBITDA. So we did Deffenbaugh RCI in Montreal, Deffenbaugh in Kansas City and SWF in South Florida. And we really don't see another one of those on the horizon. We've looked at a number of deals in the Southeast and some other places where what you said is exactly right. Sellers have gotten a little bit undisciplined on what they want. We're generally willing to pay sort of 6 to 8x EBITDA given the synergies we can pull out for a bigger deal. We might paying 7 to 9x EBITDA again because we can get good synergies and post synergies, we can get it to sort of 6 to 7.5x EBITDA. The part of the problem is, we've got a lot of the solid waste sellers that want 12x EBITDA. And that's just not a number that really works for us. And so we really don't see one of those decent sized solid waste acquisitions on the near horizon. We aren't looking dramatically outside our core solid waste. As Jim said, if we saw some opportunistic buying on the industrial side or energy services, we'd look at that. But we are not currency actively looking at anything in that arena. So we're sort of active to what I would say our smaller tuck-in acquisitions, sort of the $10 million to $20 million type acquisitions and we ask our business developers to pick up the pace on those, to make up for the fact that we don't have any of those larger transactions on the horizon. And so you know the deal. These things go in cycles. There are not a lot of buyers out there. You really haven't seen a dramatic amount of activity in the M&A side. And so -- and I think that's probably because a lot of these sellers have heightened expectations as the industry dynamics have improved. I would say that the industry is showing just as much discipline on the M&A side as they are on the operational and pricing side. No one's out there paying crazy numbers. So those businesses are going to be solved. It's just a matter of when they get to a reasonable multiple.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine of Imperial Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Levine of Imperial Capital.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to push a little bit more on the guidance revision and what's behind it. It looks like the recycling business did a little bit better than you were budgeting for in the first half of the year. 1Q, exceptionally strong, volumes seasonally. May be
componenttext: Just want to push a little bit more on the guidance revision and what's behind it. It looks like the recycling business did a little bit better than you were budgeting for in the first half of the year. 1Q, exceptionally strong, volumes seasonally. May be a little bit more detail on explicitly what's behind the guidance range? And also, I know you don't give guidance first half versus second half. But say this is mostly just outperformance in the first half or is there factors that continue to lend themselves to upside in the back half of the year and beyond?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. When I look at the first half of the year, and the outperformance in recycling, the outperformance in recycling is sort of offset by the underperformance on our leachate costs, which was as we said, we're up $22 million this quarter, so those actuall
componenttext: Yes. When I look at the first half of the year, and the outperformance in recycling, the outperformance in recycling is sort of offset by the underperformance on our leachate costs, which was as we said, we're up $22 million this quarter, so those actually is a slight negative overall. And so from a business point of view. When I look at the year, it's the plain and simple stuff. It's the blocking and tackling. Price volume and cost controls, right? And so we've seen steady progress on all 3 of those. We don't expect that to slow down. And so the back half of the year obviously, ramps up a little bit more than the first half of the year. But we're pretty optimistic that we're going to continue to see the strong performance continue again. It's blocking and tackling, price volume costs.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Fair enough, thanks. And as my follow-up, not the beat a dead horse on residential. I don't recall, Jim down 3.5% on volume. I don't recall offhand if that's better than it's been. Or maybe just a little bit more elaboration on what's driving the
componenttext: Got it. Fair enough, thanks. And as my follow-up, not the beat a dead horse on residential. I don't recall, Jim down 3.5% on volume. I don't recall offhand if that's better than it's been. Or maybe just a little bit more elaboration on what's driving the weakness? And it sounds like you're doing some things on the pricing side that's working well. But how fixable is this? Or is this kind of an issue phenomenon? And how confident are you that this business, just in general that the metrics improved going forward?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look it's about the same, I mean last quarter was negative 3 4. We've had some 2 6s and last year, we had a couple of negative 3 6s on volume. So it's not been a great volume business for us. By the way, a lot of that is by design. But I think the ch
componenttext: Yes, look it's about the same, I mean last quarter was negative 3 4. We've had some 2 6s and last year, we had a couple of negative 3 6s on volume. So it's not been a great volume business for us. By the way, a lot of that is by design. But I think the changes that Jim talked about in those contracts are kind of back to David's point of derisking the business, are helping to derisk the line of business. And then I think it's very important that we -- we've had some very stiff competition within the resi line of business. And so it's important for us to continue to push disposal price increases in addition to collection price increases. We're pushing collection price increases through this residential line of business on our customers. But I think it's important that we push disposal price increases on our third-party customers as well. I mean, they should have to pay their fair share.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is there any certain class of competitor where you're seeing the issue as large residential contracts versus intense competition for them and landfill price as a lever to drive improvement? Or is there more to it through that.
componenttext: And is there any certain class of competitor where you're seeing the issue as large residential contracts versus intense competition for them and landfill price as a lever to drive improvement? Or is there more to it through that.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. Jim Trevathan. I think part of the issue on some of the volume loss, not all of it. But enough that its measurable, are from our local competitors, when you look at interest rates where they are, they can lease trucks really at a really low co
componenttext: Yes, Scott. Jim Trevathan. I think part of the issue on some of the volume loss, not all of it. But enough that its measurable, are from our local competitors, when you look at interest rates where they are, they can lease trucks really at a really low cost and come in and take some of the neighborhoods for example, that are around the Houston area. They probably don't have the capital -- the capability from a capital standpoint to handle one of the larger locations or franchises. But they put pricing pressure on some of those local neighborhoods where they can get a couple of trucks really, really inexpensively. And I -- that's part of the effects. What we do is look at it from an integrated standpoint. As Jim Fish said, we're integrating and handing the disposal internally and it's not flow control to another disposal site then we're going to retain that business. Where it's not, we'll turn that volume lose where it's a low collection margin and put that capital to get the return.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the beauty of that is when you see that local competitor take on sort of the moderate-sized residential contract. Generally, what happens if they lose their focus on the commercial and industrial sites. So they're adding trucks in the residential side
componenttext: And the beauty of that is when you see that local competitor take on sort of the moderate-sized residential contract. Generally, what happens if they lose their focus on the commercial and industrial sites. So they're adding trucks in the residential side. We don't have any problem with that as long as they're not adding trucks on the commercial and industrial side. So for us, it's really a matter of balance. Where do you want to invest your capital? And for us, we'd much rather invest our capital on the commercial industrial side, than on the residential side.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Feniger of Bank of America ML.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Feniger of Bank of America ML.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: With maybe not a large transactions on the horizon and with free cash flow coming stronger than expected, could we be maybe see more put to share buybacks or dividend growth perhaps? How are you guys thinking about that?
componenttext: With maybe not a large transactions on the horizon and with free cash flow coming stronger than expected, could we be maybe see more put to share buybacks or dividend growth perhaps? How are you guys thinking about that?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's really a great question. And as we've said many times, our first priority would be to reinvested in the business through acquisitions. The fact that we don't have one in the horizon doesn't mean these things happen fairly quickly. So we want to
componenttext: Yes. It's really a great question. And as we've said many times, our first priority would be to reinvested in the business through acquisitions. The fact that we don't have one in the horizon doesn't mean these things happen fairly quickly. So we want to make sure that we keep enough powder dry that if something comes along, we're able to act and act fast without leveraging out the balance sheet to dramatically. So we're always going to save a little bit of dry powder to make sure that we can do any of those acquisitions that come along. And then when we look at it. Obviously, our dividend yield has gone down with a stock price going up. And so at the end of the year when we look at our dividend, I would expect that we'll see another increase in the dividend coming into the back half of the year. And then on the share repurchase side. The bulk of the remainder of our cash close to our share repurchase. We don't really time share repurchases. And so we're going to ultimately do sort of $500 million to $800 million of share repurchases every year and I'd expect to see that continue.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And on the churn rate. I guess, how low can that go? What's the ceiling? Or I guess, a better term is what's the floor? How should we think about that progression?
componenttext: Great. And on the churn rate. I guess, how low can that go? What's the ceiling? Or I guess, a better term is what's the floor? How should we think about that progression?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, we ask ourselves that same question regularly. In the vicinity of 5%, a structural churn, it's businesses, small businesses that open and then come and go. So we, probably at this point, have about 400 basis points to play with. We actually
componenttext: Yes, Michael, we ask ourselves that same question regularly. In the vicinity of 5%, a structural churn, it's businesses, small businesses that open and then come and go. So we, probably at this point, have about 400 basis points to play with. We actually expect it to stay in single digits. And whether our next goal is to get it below that 9 number into the 8. I think that is an achievable goal over the next few quarters next year or 2. And that's what we're after. We won't -- and that's affected both by service, by how we handle customer issues as they come up. It -- I think the fair scope tool will help us in that regard and help us focus price increases in customer segments that tend to accept them better. And therefore, reduce the churn number. Some of the process issues I mentioned earlier will help us in that regard. But a lot of it boils down to much better just front-line service provision that our deal guys are 100% focused on.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Tyler Brown of Raymond James.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Tyler Brown of Raymond James.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congrats on swinging the pendulum over to the positive side on commercial volume. But Jim Trevathan, can you talk a little bit about the front-load fleet? How much excess capacity do you have in that fleet? And how much volume growth do you think you can
componenttext: Congrats on swinging the pendulum over to the positive side on commercial volume. But Jim Trevathan, can you talk a little bit about the front-load fleet? How much excess capacity do you have in that fleet? And how much volume growth do you think you can absorb before you would have to see a bump in CapEx?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Tyler. We have plenty of capacity. There are a handful of markets where we've added some front-load capacity on the route side. But our system has plenty of capacity when you look across the whole network to handle more volume. There are places, as I
componenttext: Yes, Tyler. We have plenty of capacity. There are a handful of markets where we've added some front-load capacity on the route side. But our system has plenty of capacity when you look across the whole network to handle more volume. There are places, as I said earlier, that we've added routes. But with the tools that we now have to service delivery optimization and SDO with the onboard computers, when we add that, we're adding it at that low cost basis rather than just a truck to hand make a handful of customers. We we route regularly with that tool and make sure that the efficiency numbers stay up. And they have as we've added volume and high-growth margins. So I don't think you're going to see a huge impact whether it's still efficiency. You'll see most of those dollars on the commercial customer additions go into the bottom line.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: By the way, Tyler, we are buying more trucks this year. We bought -- we probably bought about 10% more trucks this year than last year. So we are buying some additional trucks and you can imagine, we're not buying a lot of resi trucks. So most of them are
componenttext: By the way, Tyler, we are buying more trucks this year. We bought -- we probably bought about 10% more trucks this year than last year. So we are buying some additional trucks and you can imagine, we're not buying a lot of resi trucks. So most of them are on the industrial line of business and also the commercial.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll buy about 1,300, about 1,315 [ph] trucks versus 1,120 last year. So we see that upside and yet our efficiency, Tyler, is still positive, about 1% year-to-date. That's a good number for us compared to historic numbers.
componenttext: We'll buy about 1,300, about 1,315 [ph] trucks versus 1,120 last year. So we see that upside and yet our efficiency, Tyler, is still positive, about 1% year-to-date. That's a good number for us compared to historic numbers.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That was actually my second question. So is that 1,300, is that a heightened replacement? Or is that more of a normal replacement cycle? I assume it's heightened.
componenttext: Yes. That was actually my second question. So is that 1,300, is that a heightened replacement? Or is that more of a normal replacement cycle? I assume it's heightened.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's heightened somewhat especially as Jim said on the industrial side because we're seeing more growth there and have consistently over the last several years, but it's -- are going to see it stay in that vicinity. We expect that volume as Dave said earl
componenttext: It's heightened somewhat especially as Jim said on the industrial side because we're seeing more growth there and have consistently over the last several years, but it's -- are going to see it stay in that vicinity. We expect that volume as Dave said earlier fast 1 and this will continue in that 1300 or so trucks on just a replacement basis.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jim Fish, may be I'm reading into it a little bit. But did your comments kind of indicate the CapEx would decline in '17 given the leachate investments or did those stick around into '17? Just any way to think about that.
componenttext: And Jim Fish, may be I'm reading into it a little bit. But did your comments kind of indicate the CapEx would decline in '17 given the leachate investments or did those stick around into '17? Just any way to think about that.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, specifically to the leachate investment, I think yes, you're going to see a decline. As we talked about kind of that $100 million and not all of it is the leachate plant, but otherwise the treatment plant. But yes, I -- specific to that, they will d
componenttext: Well, specifically to the leachate investment, I think yes, you're going to see a decline. As we talked about kind of that $100 million and not all of it is the leachate plant, but otherwise the treatment plant. But yes, I -- specific to that, they will decline. Now there are some other things that could affected if we win a big contract for example, next year that might offset some of that. But not knowing that at this point, I would say that we would see at least a partial decline and off of this kind of 1 4 -- 1 4 5 number.

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very helpful. And in this is a housekeeping question. I apologize. I got on the call late, but what was the $40 million expense in the other line that was below EBIT? And can you give us any help on how to think about that line going forward?
componenttext: Okay. Very helpful. And in this is a housekeeping question. I apologize. I got on the call late, but what was the $40 million expense in the other line that was below EBIT? And can you give us any help on how to think about that line going forward?

headline: Waste Management, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. In a year where there doesn't seem to be a lot of good presidential news, we actually have some good presidential news here at Waste Management. Today, we'll be issuing a press release and we're going to file an 8-K, announcing that we're promo
componenttext:
Thank you. In a year where there doesn't seem to be a lot of good presidential news, we actually have some good presidential news here at Waste Management. Today, we'll be issuing a press release and we're going to file an 8-K, announcing that we're promoting Jim Fish to the role of President. I wish I could promote him to role of President of the United States, but unfortunately, all I can do is promote him to President of Waste Management. 
As part of our ongoing succession planning process, the board and I felt that the next logical step in that process was for us to name Jim, President. We're conducting a search for a new, Chief Financial Officer who will report to Jim. And while that search is underway, Jim will retain his CFO responsibilities. Obviously, you all on the phone, know Jim very well. Many of you have worked with him for a while now, so you know why the board and I have such confidence in him. He's really been pivotal to the success of our company and he's also a talented leader with tremendous knowledge of all aspects of our business. 
The promotion is a well-deserved recognition of his past accomplishments and another step in his development as a leader. I'm sure you'll all join me, our board, our senior leadership team and the rest of our Waste Management family in congratulating Jim on this great achievement. 
And with that, operator, we'll see you next quarter. Thank you.
